'gro ba thams cad la gnas pa mi mnga' zhing mnyam pa nyid kyi rjes su bzhud pa/ spyod pa tha dad pa las byung ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i stobs bcu bsgribs pa med pa/ mngon par sangs rgyas pa/ thugs la chags pa mi mnga' bas rtag tu mnyam par bzhag cing ma 'dres pa/ ye shes thams cad la rnam par spyod pa/ don dang tshig dang yi ge la dad pa yang dag par ston pa/ ye shes rgya mtsho mtha' dang dbus med pa la bzhugs pa/ yon tan gyi mchog ye shes kyi snying pos byung bas chos kyi dbyings thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi nyi ma shar ba/

Regarding all living beings impartially, his mind had no attachments. He dwelt in the abode of nonobstruction and had attained the ten powers of buddhahood without impediment. His mind was always quiet and stable, never distracted or disturbed. Abiding in omniscience, he was able to express all kinds of truths. Able to enter completely into the boundless ocean of knowledge, he produced infinite treasuries of virtue and wisdom. With the sun of enlightenment he constantly illumined the entire cosmos.

'gro ba thams cad du sngon gyi smon lam zad pa mi mnga' bar chos kyi dbyings kyi rang bzhin la gnas pa/ sangs rgyas kyi rnam par spyod pa ma nyams pa brnyes pa/ bdag gi dang yongs su gzung ba med pas gnas pa mi mnga' ba/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i chos thams cad 'byung zhing / 'jig rten gyi chos thams cad kyis ma gos pa/ 'gro ba thams cad kyi mi shes pa'i rgyal mtshan yang dag par bcad pa/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi mi shes pa chen po yongs su bsal ba'i gnas su gyur pa/ 'gro ba thams cad snang bar mngon par 'don pa/ 'jig rten thams cad ye shes khyad par du 'phags pa la rab tu gzhog pa/ 'gro ba thams cad nye bar 'tsho ba'i bsod nams yongs su mi zad pa/

In accord with the power of his original vows, he was always manifest, never disappearing, always dwelling in the realm of reality, abiding in the abode of Buddhas, without change. He had no attachment to self or to possessions. He dwelt in the transmundane state and was not affected by mundane things. In all worlds he set up the banner of knowledge and wisdom, his knowledge vast and great, transcending the world, with no attachments. He rescued sentient beings from the mire, placing them on the highest ground of wisdom. All his blessings and virtues benefited sentient beings yet were never exhausted.

byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi shes pa thugs su chud pas dad par bya bar 'os pa/ yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas su gzhol ba'i byams pa chen po las byung ba/ thugs rje chen po yang dag par ston pas spyod pa/ sangs rgyas kyi sku brjod du med pa'i chos dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos sna tshogs bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i gsung dang dbyangs kyi char 'bebs pa/ sems can gyi bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du yang dag par tshim par mdzad pa/ sngon gyi mtha' dang / phyi ma'i mtha' dang / da ltar byung ba'i mtha' dmigs pa'i byin rlabs shin tu dag cing bsam gyis mi khyab pas sems can dag par mdzad pa; byang chub sems dpa' thams cad lung bstan pa rgyun mi 'chad pa/ sangs rgyas kyi rigs su dbang bskur bas de bzhin gshegs pa'i rgyud du byung ba/

He was fully aware of the knowledge and wisdom of all enlightening beings, their faith and direction certain, sure to attain enlightenment. By great compassion he manifested infinite adornments of the buddha-body. With a wondrous voice he expounded infinite teachings, satisfying sentient beings according to their mentalities. In the past, future, and present, his mind was always pure. He caused all sentient beings to be unattached to objects. He constantly forecast the enlightenment of all the enlightening beings, causing them to enter the family of Buddhas to be born in the house of Buddhas, and attain the coronation of Buddhas.

'jig rten thams cad du 'khor lo mi ldog par 'khor ba/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi mngon par zhen pa thams cad las 'phags pa/ sangs rgyas kyi zhing dang / chos kyi dbyings thams cad kyi mtha' klas pa la mi gnas pa/ 'gro ba thams cad mnyam pa nyid du thugs su chud pa/ 'jig rten las 'das pa'i bsod nams kyis rnam par dag pa; 'khor ba la mi bzhugs par 'jig rten thams cad du snang bar gyur pa/ btsal ba mi dmigs pas chos kyi dbyings thams cad kyi rang bzhin/ ye shes kyi zla ba de bzhin gshegs pa tshad med pa'i rjes su bzhud pa/ sgyu ma lta bu'i ye shes kyis byin gyis rlob pa/ mig yor lta bu'i ye shes kyis rnam par ston pa/ rmi lam lta bur rjes su dran pa/ sprul pa dang mnyam par byung ba/ sems kyi rang bzhin lta bur 'jig rten sna tshogs thams cad byin gyis rlob pa/ las kyi rnam par smin pa'i tshul dang / bsam pa ji lta ba bzhin du sems can gyi skye mched rnam par phye ba yang dag par ston pa/ sems can gyi dbang po dang mthun par sangs rgyas kyi sku byung ba/

He always traveled throughout the ten directions, never resting, never craving for or clinging to anything. Able to live in all buddha-lands in the cosmos, he knew the minds of all sentient beings. All his virtues were unworldly and pure. He did not dwell in birth and death, yet appeared throughout the world, like a reflection. He illumined the whole cosmos by the moon of knowledge and realized that everything is ungraspable. By his wisdom he was constantly aware that all worlds are like illusions, like reflections, like dreams, like magic tricks, that all have mind as their inherent nature. Abiding in this way, he manifested buddha-bodies in accord with the dissimilarities of the actions and consequences of sentient beings, the distinctions in their mental inclinations, and the individual differences in their faculties.

de bzhin gshegs pa'i dmigs pa la sems can grangs med pa'i sems yang dag par gnas pa/ 'jig rten thams cad rten cing 'brel bar 'byung ba rnam par bsten pa'i rang bzhin du chos kyi mtshan nyid kyis yang dag par spyod pa/ ye shes kyi rgyud mtshan nyid med pa'i rang bzhin dang mtshan nyid gcig tu gyur pa/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi rang bzhin gyi mtshan nyid snang ba mngon par sgrub pa'i spyod pa yang dag par ston cing / 'gro ba thams cad gdon par brtson pa/ sangs rgyas kyi spyod yul bla na med pa yang dag par ston pa/ 'jig rten dang zhing thams cad yongs su skyob pas sangs rgyas kyi mtshan ma gzung bar 'jig rten du mngon par byung ba/ 'jig rten gyi nyon mongs pa'i mtshan ma thams cad rnam par bsal ba/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi rjes su dran pa dang / dmigs par 'byor bar gyur pa/ 'khrug pa med par khong du chud par 'gyur ba'i rgyu theg pa chen pos zhal yongs su rgyas pa/ chos thams cad kyi don grub pa/

The Enlightened One was always relating to countless sentient beings, explaining to them that everything in the world derives from conditional, interdependent origination. He knew that the signs of all things are signless, this being their sole characteristic, the basis of wisdom. He wanted to cause all sentient beings to detach from all signs, forms, and characteristics. He showed clearly all natures and characteristics of the world, thus traversing the world; to reveal to them unexcelled enlightenment, desiring to rescue all sentient beings, he appeared in the world and showed the way of the enlightened. He caused them to perceive the features of the body of the enlightened one, to concentrate on them and meditate on them, to diligently cultivate and develop themselves to annihilate mundane afflictions, cultivate enlightening practice with unwavering minds, and attain fulfillment of all aspects of the Great Vehicle, attaining the rewards of the Buddhas.

'gro ba thams cad kyi dge ba'i rtsa bas rnam par phye ba/ nyams pa med pa'i 'phrin las rnam par smin pas rnam par dag pa/ ye shes kyi 'byung gnas dus gsum mnyam pa nyid du thugs su chud pa/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi yongs su rtog pa yongs su mi rtog pas byung ba/ 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du 'od zer gyi dra bas gsal bar gyur pa/ phyogs bcu 'byams klas pa thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi 'od kyis snang bar mdzad pa/

He was able to observe the roots of goodness of sentient beings, and did not allow the results of their pure deeds to die out. His knowledge was clear and complete entering into all times, forever detached from all mundane discrimination. He radiated networks of light beams, fully illuminating all worlds in the ten directions.

sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rjes su bzhud pa blta bas mi ngoms shing btang mi bra ba/ yon tan chen po dang / ye shes dang / mngon par shes pa dang / byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa 'byung ba dang / dbang po mngon par mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi spyod yul can/ ye shes kyi dkyil 'khor gyis sangs rgyas kyi mdzad pa rgyas par mdzad pa/ sangs rgyas kyi 'phrin las shin tu sgrub pa nub cing /

Those who saw him never tired of beholding the sublime refinements of his physical form. By means of great virtue, knowledge, wisdom, and spiritual power, he produced all kinds of enlightening practices. The spheres of his senses were free and complete, round and full. He did Buddha-work, and when he finished doing it he disappeared.

'das pa dang / ma 'ongs pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i thams cad mkhyen pa'i tshul ston pa/ byang chub sems dpa'i gzungs mtha' yas pa'i char 'bebs pa/ bsam pa yangs pa'i sgom pa yongs su 'dzin par mdzad pa/ sangs rgyas kyi dpal thams cad kyis rab tu 'bar ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku kha dog mtha' yas pa sna tshogs su 'jig rten thams cad la mngon par ston pa/

He was able to show the path of all knowledge of past, present, and future. For the enlightening beings he showered a rain of innumerable concentration formulae, causing them to develop great rapture, to take them up, hold them, and practice them, and perfect the virtues of all Buddhas, in their full glory, with boundless wonderful forms, to adorn their beings.

sgrib pa'i chos thams cad du ma lhung ba/ chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin gyis don gyis dag pa/ yon tan gyi chos thams cad la mnga' bas mdzes pa'i dkyil 'khor can/ yon tan gyi 'od zer mnga' ba'i nyi mar gyur pa/ bsod nams kyi zhing du shar ba/ gzi brjid thams cad kyi dra bas mngon par skyes pa/

He saw everything in all worlds, and was forever rid of all obstruction. He had attained the pure true meaning of all verities. He had attained mastery of virtuous qualities, and was a great king of truth, like the sun illumining everywhere. Being a field of blessings for the world, he had great dignity, influence, and virtue.

'jig rten thams cad du sangs rgyas kyis sprul pa yang dag par 'dzin pa/ 'jig rten thams cad sprul par thugs su chud pa'i ye shes snang ba dang ldan pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i go 'phang chags pa med pa mnga' ba/ phyi ma'i mtha'i yon tan 'jig rten thams cad kyis rnam par shes pa/ 'gro ba thams cad dang mthun par ston pa'i ye shes kyi phyag mnga' ba/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i ye shes kyi sman pa/ sems can thams cad bde bar mdzad pa/ 'jig rten tshad med pa thams cad du shin tu rnam par dag pas rjes su 'brang ba/ 'gro ba dang zhing 'byams klas pa thams cad du phyir mi ldog pa/

He manifested emanation bodies in all worlds, radiating the light of wisdom, causing all to be enlightened. Wanting to cause all sentient beings to know the boundless virtues possessed by the Buddha, he took the turban of nonobstruction, tied it on his head, and assumed the rank of Budhahood. Adapting to the world, he guided by means of expedient methods, comforting beings with the hand of wisdom. As a great physician, he skillfully cured all sickness, able to go to all the countless lands in all worlds, without rest.

ye shes kyi spyan phugs rab rib med cing rnam par dag pa/ sangs rgyas kyi lo legs pa yang dag par ston pa/ 'khu ba'i sems can gyi khams las su rung bar mdzad pa/ 'dul ba sna tshogs du ma la 'jug pa/ dus bzhin du 'dul ba'i rgyun mi 'chad pa/ 'gro ba thams cad la mnyam pa'i thugs kyis yang dag par spyod pa las skyon med pa'i rnam par smin pa dang / mya ngan las 'das pa yang dag par ston pa; bsam pa dang / las dang / rgyu mthun pa'i 'bras bu ji lta ba bzhin du sangs rgyas kyi sku rnam par ston pa/ sangs rgyas kyi sku ji lta ba bzhin du sems can gyis chos shes pa 'byung bar mdzad pa/ sangs rgyas kyis sprul pa byin gyis rlob pa/ 'jig rten gyi chos thams cad la rnam par gzigs pa'i ye shes mnga' ba/ dga' ba chen po dang lhag pa'i bsam pas dbang po dga' bar mdzad pa/ sangs rgyas mthong ba'i dad pa'i shugs mtha' yas pas byung ba/ sems can thams cad kyi rang gi dge ba'i rtsa ba phyir mi ldog par mdzad pa/

His clear, pure eye of wisdom was free from all obstructions, able to clearly see all. Evil-doing sentient beings he tamed in various ways, causing them to enter the Path, skillfully seizing appropriate opportunities to civilize and teach them, never ceasing. If sentient beings developed equanimous, impartial minds, he would then show them the consequences of impartial deeds. In accord with their inclinations and in accord with their actions and results thereof, he manifested various spiritual powers of the buddha-body for them, to expound the truth and enlighten them, that they may attain the knowledge and wisdom of the teaching, and that their minds be joyful and their senses ecstatic, that they see innumerable Buddhas, develop profound faith, and produce roots of goodness, never regressing.

sems can gyi las ji lta ba bzhin du rjes su 'brang bar mdzad pa/ 'gro ba gnyid kyis log pa thams cad sad par mdzad pa/ sangs rgyas skye bas dge ba yang dag par 'phel bar mdzad pa/ sems can la sangs rgyas kyi bag dbab pa/ chen po stobs pa mdzad pa/ 'jig rten gyi lta ba thams cad la mi gnas pa; ye shes kyi don la rab tu gzhog pa/ rab tu gzhag pa'i ye shes kyi tshul gyi spyod yul thugs su chud pa/ sangs rgyas kyis gzigs pa'i zil gyis non pa'i rgyan gyis brgyan pa/ chos kyi rgyud thugs su chud pa'i ri bo rnam par dag pa/

All sentient beings, in accord with their involvement and entrapment by actions, sleep forever in birth-and-death; the Enlightened One, appearing in the world, can awaken them all, comfort their minds, and cause them to be without anxiety or fear. Any who see him he causes to realize independent knowledge of truth. With knowledge and skill in means he comprehends the objective world. His embellishing marks and adornments cannot be overshadowed. His mountain of wisdom and talons of teaching are all purified.

sangs rgyas 'byams klas pa dang / byang chub sems dpa' gzhan dang gzhan du ston pa/ kha na ma tho ba med pa'i sa la sems can rab tu 'god pa/ sangs rgyas kyi yon tan grangs med pas rnam par bris pa/ las kyis sna tshogs su gyur pa'i 'jig rten du de bzhin gshegs pa sna tshogs yang dag par ston pa/ sangs rgyas kyi 'byung gnas rnam par sbyong ba/ ye shes thams cad yongs su 'thob par mdzad pa/

Sometimes he manifests as an enlightening being, sometimes he appears as a Buddha, causing all sentient beings to arrive at the realm of sorrowlessness. Adorned by countless virtues, developed by practical action, he appears in the world. The adornment and purity of all Buddhas are accomplished by the works of omniscience.

'jig rten thams cad kyi smon lam rjes su srung ba/ mi shigs pa/ 'gro ba thams cad la dge ba'i bshes gnyen ston pa/ snang ba dri ma med cing mchog tu dag par mdzad pa/ 'gro ba ma lus pa thams cad kyis ji tsam du mngon sum du mthong ba de tsam du brjod du med pa/ sems can thams cad kyi 'gro ba'i rjes su song ba'i byin gyi rlabs mnga' ba/ grogs sngon du 'gro ba'i dge ba'i rtsa bas sems can rnam par dag par mdzad pa/ 'gro ba thams cad kyi smon lam gyi rjes su song ba/ nyams pa med pa/ sems can thams cad kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba yongs su bzung bas dag par mdzad pa las bsags pa'i tshul gyis yongs su byung ba/ bdud kyi dkrug ma thams cad rnam par 'joms par byung ba/

Always keeping his original vow, he does not abandon the world, being a steadfast benefactor of sentient beings. His supreme pure light makes itself visible to all sentient beings. By means of spiritual power, the Buddha always follows the sentient beings of the six realms of mundane existence, boundless and countless, never abandoning them. If there are any who have planted similar roots of goodness in the past, he causes them all to be purified, yet without giving up his original vow with regard to all sentient beings of the six paths of mundane existence. He deceives no one, appropriately dealing with them in virtuous ways, causing them to practice pure acts and break up demonic conflicts.

chags pa med pa'i mtha'i stobs kyis byung ba/ 'gro ba thams cad kyis blta na 'od shin tu dang bar snang ba/ ye shes kyi dbyings chags pa med pa'i snying po'i nyi ma sems can gang yang rung ba la chos kyi sbyin pa mdzad pa/ 'od zer gyi dkyil 'khor gyi mdzod mtha' dang dbus med pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i stobs kyi ye shes kyi dkyil 'khor mnga' ba/ 'gro ba thams cad la snang bar gyur pa/ bsam pa dang yang dag par rtogs pa thams cad yongs su rdzogs pa/ phyir rgol ba shin tu bcom pa/ yon tan gyi gnas dam pa mchog tu gyur pa/ 'gro ba thams cad kyi rten du gyur pa/ yon tan tshad med par gyur pa/ 'gro ba thams cad yongs su dag par mdzad pa; dge ba'i rtsa ba chung ngu tshad med par yongs su 'dzin pa/ zad mi shes pa'i ye shes kyi sar 'dzud cing rab tu gzhog pa/ 'jig rten thams cad kyi dge ba'i rtsa ba sems la rag lus par yid ches pas tshad med pa'i bsod nams dang yon tan dag par mdzad pa/ ye shes kyi tshul gyis ngan song gsum gyi 'gro ba yongs su skyob pa'o/ /zhes

From the realm of nonobstruction he produces great power. Nothing blocks his supreme treasury of light. He manifests reflections in the realm of pure minds, which all worlds see. He bestows many various teachings on sentient beings. Buddha is a boundless treasury of light; his powers, knowledge, and wisdom are all fully complete. He constantly illumines all sentient beings with great light, causing them all to be fulfilled in accordance with their aspirations. Beyond all enmity, he is the highest field of blessings, relied upon by all sentient beings; if any give anything, he causes them to be pure, and to receive boundless blessings from doing a little bit of good. He causes all to be able to enter the stage of inexhaustible knowledge. He is the pure-minded master, planting roots of goodness for all sentient beings. He is the most excellent fertile field producing blessings and merit for sentient beings. His knowledge and wisdom is exceedingly deep; with skill in means he can rescue all from the pains of the woeful states of greed, anger, and ignorance.

rnam pa de lta bur de bzhin gshegs pa la mos pa/ rnam pa de lta bur yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas la yang dag par lta ba/ rnam pa de lta bur ye shes kyi mu stegs las 'bab pa/ rnam pa de lta bu'i yon tan rgya mtsho'i gang chen mtsho thams cad la 'jug pa/ rnam pa de lta bu'i ye shes kyi nam mkha'i rjes su phyin par rjes su 'gro ba/ rnam pa de lta bur 'gro ba thams cad kyi bsod nams kyi zhing du yang dag pa ji lta bar shes pa/ rnam pa de lta bur de bzhin gshegs pa dran pa'i sgos lta ba/ rnam pa de lta bur dge ba'i 'phrin las rnam par dag pa'i mtshan nyid phun sum tshogs pas de bzhin gshegs pa la rtog pa/ rnam pa de lta bu'i yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi sku chen po 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du snang bar byed pa/ rnam pa de lta bu'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul ba thams cad yang dag par bstan pa rjes su sems pa de dag gis de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bcom ldan 'das kyi ba spu'i sgo re re nas 'od zer bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong grangs med pa 'byung ba/ grangs med par rnam par dag pa/ grangs med par shin tu snang ba/ grangs med par bltar yod pa/ grangs med pa'i sems can gyi dga' ba skyed pa/ grangs med pa'i spro ba skyed pa; grangs med pa'i sangs rgyas la 'dun pa rnam par 'phel bar byed pa/ grangs med pa'i lhag ba'i bsam pa rnam par sbyong ba/ grangs med pa'i dbang po sim par byed pa; grangs med pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i spyod yul thob par byed pa mang po mthong bar gyur to/ /

Thus believing, thus observing, thus entering the depths of knowledge, thus sporting in the ocean of virtues, thus arriving at spacelike wisdom, thus cognizing sentient beings’ field of blessings, thus contemplating with presence of mind, thus observing the deeds, marks and embellishments of Buddha, thus observing the Buddha appearing throughout the world, thus observing the Buddha’s mystical power, the great congregation at that time saw each pore of the Buddha’s body emit a hundred trillion infinities of light beams, each beam of light having countless hues, countless purities, countless radiances, causing countless beings to watch, countless beings to rejoice, countless beings to be happy, countless beings to grow in faith, countless beings’ aspiration to be pure, countless beings’ senses to be pure and cool, and causing countless beings to develop respect and honor.

'od kyi 'khor lo bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong bsam gyis mi khyab pa yang de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku las rnam par 'phrul pa sna tshogs kyis 'phrul zhing 'byung ba/ kha dog bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ mdog bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ 'od bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ chos kyi dbyings mtha' dang dbus med pa thams cad rgyas par byed pa/ sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs dang / sems can rnam par dag pas dri zhim por rab tu byung ba/ tshigs su bcad pa bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong bsam gyis mi khyab pa yongs su 'dzin pa/ 'jig rten thams cad las rnam par 'das shing / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dge ba'i rtsa bas yongs su byung ba/ rgyan bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong bsam gyis mi khyab pa/ yang dag par ston pa/ bskal pa bye ba khrag khrig bsam gyis mi khyab par yon tan mi zad pa/ sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa zad mi shes pa las byung ba/ sangs rgyas skye ba brjod du med pa yang dag par ston pa/ ye shes kyi sgo la rab tu gzhog pa/ don yangs pa shin tu ston pa/ sangs rgyas kyi sprul pa brjod du med pa'i tshul yang dag par ston pa/ sangs rgyas kyi yul mtha' dang dbus med pa/ chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa/ nam mkha'i khams kyi mthar thug pa/ 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du byin gyi rlabs kyis byung ba/ 'gro ba thams cad rnam par dag pa/ mnyam pa nyid kyi rjes su song ba/ thams cad mkhyen pa chags pa med pa/ mtha' dang dbus med pa'i sangs rgyas kyi spyod pa las byung ba; de bzhin gshegs pa bsam gyis mi khyab pas bsten pa'i dpal yod pa/ rin po che'i 'od 'phro ba bye ba brgya stong bsam gyis mi khyab pa de ltar byung ba mthong bar gyur to; ; bcom ldan 'das kyis kyang byin gyi rlabs kyis rgyan smon lam chen po las byung ba'i dge ba'i rtsa ba mtha' yas pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa mnyes par bya ba'i spyod pas rnam par dag pa dang / sngon gyi bag yod pa las yang dag par byung ba'i thams cad mkhyen pa'i sems chags pa med pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba las byung ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa 'byams klas pa 'gro ba thams cad kyi the tshom gcod pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa mthong ba la sems can tshad med pa rab tu dgod pa dang / dge ba'i rtsa ba'i sgo dang / sangs rgyas kyi cho 'phrul zil gyis non pa med pa la rgya mtsho'i mthas gtugs pa'i sems can gzud par bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' bka' bzhin byed pa thams cad sangs rgyas kyi zhing kun nas 'dus pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs dang / sangs rgyas kyi chos bsam gyis mi khyab pa yongs su brjod pa'i tshul gyis

Then the great assembly all saw the Buddha’s body emit a hundred trillion infinities of inconceivable great lights, each light with inconceivably many hues and inconceivable many beams illumining inconceivably many realms of phenomena, by the Buddha’s spiritual power producing great subtle sound conveying infinites of eulogies in words transcending all worlds, perfected by transmundane virtues. He also manifested hundreds of trillions of quadrillions of inconceivable numbers of subtle adornments, which could never be fully described even in a hundred trillion quadrillion inconceivable number of eons, all of them produced by the inexhaustible spiritual power of the Buddha. He also manifested unspeakably many enlightened ones arising in the world and leading sentient beings into the door of wisdom to understand the most profound truth. He also manifested the docetic metamorphoses of the enlightened ones throughout the space of the cosmos, causing all worldly beings to be impartial and purified. All of this sprung from the unhindered omniscience in which the Buddha dwelt. It was also born of the inconceivable superlative virtues which the Buddha cultivated. He also manifested a hundred trillion quadrillion inconceivable numbers of beautiful jewel light flames, originating from the good roots of his ancient great vows. He did so because he had presented offerings to and served countless enlightened ones, because he had cultivated pure practices without slacking, because his omniscient mind, without impediment, produced roots of virtue, in order to reveal the universality of the powers of the enlightened, to cut off the doubts of all sentient beings, to cause all of them to be able to see the enlightened one, to cause infinite sentient beings to abide in virtue, to show the enlightened one’s spiritual powers cannot be outshone, to cause all sentient beings to be able to enter into the ocean of the ultimate, to cause the enlightening beings of all buddha-lands to assemble, and because he wanted to reveal the inconceivable teachings of the Buddha.

de bzhin gshegs pa'i 'khor du ji ltar sangs rgyas kyi zhing 'byams klas pa khrag khrig brgya stong brjod du med pa grangs med pa dag na sems ma dad pa rnams dad par bya ba dang / sems dad pa rnams rnam par 'phel bar bya ba dang / sems rnam par 'phel ba rnams rnam par dag par bya ba dang / sems rnam par dag pa rnams yongs su smin par bya ba dang / sems yongs su smin pa rnams 'dul bar bya ba dang / chos zab mo khong du chud par bya ba dang / ye shes snang ba mtha' dang dbus med pa khong du chud par bya ba dang / sems tshad med pa rnams rgya che bar bya ba dang / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du sems bskyed pa las phyir mi ldog par bya ba dang / chos nyid dang mi 'gal bar bya ba dang / yang dag pa'i mthas mi skrag par bya ba dang / de bzhin nyid rab tu rtogs par bya ba dang / pha rol tu phyin pa rnams kyang rab tu rdzogs par bya ba dang / 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba rnam par sbyang bar bya ba dang / dmigs pa thams cad la brtson pa'i sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa yang kun tu bzang po'i tshul du mos par bya ba dang / bdud kyi yul las rnam par ldog par bya ba dang / sangs rgyas kyi yul 'thob par bya ba dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos nyid shes par bya ba dang / ye shes bsam gyis mi khyab pa skye bar bya ba dang / theg pa chen po'i smon lam las phyir mi ldog par bya ba dang / sangs rgyas blta ba las mi 'phang bar bya ba dang / ye shes khong du chud par bya ba tshad med pa rtogs par bya ba dang / sa mtshams med pa'i bsod nams kyi stobs yang dag par yongs su bsgrub par bya ba dang / shin tu dga' ba'i sems bskyed par bya ba dang / the tshom med pa'i sa la 'jug par bya ba dang / kha na ma tho ba med cing yongs su dag pa 'thob par bya ba dang / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid la brten pa so sor thob par bya ba dang / chos mthong ba las phyir mi ldog par bya ba dang / byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi tshogs kyi rjes su 'jug par bya ba dang / dus gsum gyi sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rigs grub par bya ba de lta de ltar bcom ldan 'das kyis thugs rje chen po kun tu khyab pa dang / thams cad mkhyen pa'i ye shes kyi phung po chen pos byin gyi rlabs kyi rgyan rnam pa tha dad pa mang po yang dag par bstan to/ / de ltar bcom ldan 'das kyis sems can thams cad 'dul ba'i dbang du sangs rgyas kyi bdag nyid che ba brjod pa'i phyir chags pa med pa'i ye shes kyi snying po rab tu snang bas sangs rgyas kyi dpal mtha' yas pa rab tu 'bar ba/ sangs rgyas kyi cho 'phrul bsam gyis mi khyab pas rnam par snang ba thams cad du bzhugs pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i skus rnam par 'phrul pa mtha' dang dbus med pa'i cho 'phrul gyi mthu dang ldan pa/ dgongs pa yongs su rdzogs pa'i sngon gyi smon lam gyis yongs su grub pa'i ye shes kyi rnam par gnon pas de bzhin gshegs pa'i gshegs stabs phun sum tshogs pa/ chos kyi dbang phyug brnyes pas chos thams cad la mnga' ba dang ldan pa/ thams cad mkhyen pa nyid kyi sgo nas byung ba'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku rnam par dag pas shin tu sbyangs pa mnga' ba; 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas thams cad dang mnyam pa nyid du gyur pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba thams cad kyis snying po shin tu sbyangs pa/ 'gro ba thams cad kyi dpes dper mi 'gyur ba'i sku gzugs mnga' ba/ mtshan thams cad kyi lo ma shin tu 'phags pa'i sku can/ stobs bcu'i rgyal mtshan gyi stobs chen po dang ldan pa; bskal pa mi zad pa thams cad du blta bas mi ngom pa/
sngon gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba ston pa'i dbyangs kyis ye shes kyi nga ror gyur pa/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad kyi dkyil 'khor mi zad pas 'gro ba thams cad la nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor du gyur pa/ yon tan thams cad kyi rgyal po chos thams cad kyi srid la mnga' ba'i phyir dus gsum snang bar byed pa'i gsung mnga' bas byin gyi rlabs kyi rgyan sngon gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i tshogs las yang dag par byung ba'i byin gyis brlabs so/ /

Then the Enlightened One, his great compassion covering all, showed the adornments of omniscience, wanting to cause the sentient beings in innumerable worlds who had no faith to have faith, to cause those with faith to develop, to cause the developed to become pure, to cause the pure to become mature, to cause the mature to conquer their minds and contemplate the profound truth, be filled with the boundless light of knowledge and wisdom, develop an immeasurably broad mind, an omniscient mind, never regressing, not going against the essential nature of things, not fearing ultimate reality, to realize genuine truth, fulfill all transcendent practices, purify all transmundane virtues, like Universally Good, attain the freedom of buddhahood, leave the realm of demons and enter the realm of Buddhas, comprehend the profound teaching and attain inconceivable knowledge, never regressing from the vows of universal salvation, to always see the Buddhas, never abandoning them, to perfect experiential knowledge, realize infinite truths, be filled with the boundless power of the treasury of virtue, develop a joyous mind, enter the realm where there is no doubt, divorce evil and be pure, see things unperturbed due to omniscience, gain entry to the congregations of all enlightening beings, and always be born in the family of the enlightened ones of past, present, and future.
These adornments manifested by the Buddha were all made by roots of goodness accumulated in the past, for the purpose of harmonizing and civilizing all sentient beings, to reveal the great powerful virtue of the enlightened, to light up the treasury of unobstructed knowledge and wisdom, to show the extreme radiance of the boundless supreme virtues of the enlightened, to show the inconceivable great spiritual displays of the enlightened, to manifest the buddha-body in all realms of being by means of spiritual powers, to show the boundlessness of the mystic powers and magical transfigurations of the enlightened, to fulfill all his original aspirations, to show that the dauntless knowledge and wisdom of the enlightened can go everywhere, to become the king of truth free in all ways, to produce all avenues of knowledge, to manifest the purity of the body of the enlightened, and also to reveal the supreme splendor of his body, to manifest the realization of the equal state of the Buddhas of all times, to reveal the pure treasury of roots of goodness, to manifest the most sublime form, to which nothing in the world may be likened, to show the characteristics of full command of the ten powers, to cause beholders never to tire, to be the sun of the world, illumining past, present, and future. All the virtuous qualities of the sovereign king of truth were manifested by roots of goodness of the past; even if all enlightening beings were to eulogize and tell of them throughout all time, they never would be exhaustively told.

de nas lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan gyis tshul 'di lta bur de bzhin gshegs pa la mchod pa dang / rim gro dang / rgyan kun tu bshams pa byas te dga' ldan gyi ris kyi lha bye ba brgya stong grangs med pa dang lhan cig tu zhes can rim gro dang bcas par bcom ldan 'das gang na ba der thal mo sbyar te phyag 'tshal nas bcom ldan 'das la 'di skad ces gsol to/ / bcom ldan 'das/ gshegs su gsol/ bde bar gshegs pa/ gshegs su gsol/ de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas bde bar gshegs sam/

Then the king of the Tushita heaven, having prepared all the offerings for the Buddha, together with countless deities of the Tushita heaven, joined his palms in a gesture of respect toward the Buddha and said, “Welcome, World Honored One; welcome, Felicitous One; welcome, Enlightened One, Worthy, Truly Awakened One! Please look upon us with compassion and sojourn in this place.”

de nas bcom ldan 'das lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan gyis spyan drangs nas sangs rgyas kyi rgyan rnam pa 'di lta bu dang / sangs rgyas kyi bdag nyid che ba 'gro ba thams cad la mdzes pa/ byang chub sems dpa' thams cad mos pa/ dga' ldan gyi ris kyi lha'i bu thams cad mngon par dga' ba/ lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan gyis mi ngoms par rim gror bya zhing / tshad med pa'i sems can sangs rgyas la dmigs par brtson pa bskyed pa/ tshad med pa'i sems can sangs rgyas su dge ba'i rtsa ba bskyed pa/ mi zad pa'i bsod nams dang ldan par gyur pa; dad pa dri ma med pa'i tshogs kyis bsags pa/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i zhal blta ba dang / mchod pas skyo bar mi 'gyur ba/ lhag pa'i bsam pa dge ba'i tshogs kyis yang dag par bsdus pa/ thams cad mkhyen pa'i dge ba'i rtsa ba dang / smon lam dang / sems bskyed pa las byung bas khang pa rin po che thams cad kyis brgyan par gshegs so; ; ji ltar bcom ldan 'das 'dir gshegs pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa dang / dga' ldan gyi gnas dag tu yang gshegs par snang ngo/ / bcom ldan 'das rin po che thams cad kyis brgyan pa'i khang par gshegs ma thag tu de'i tshe rin po che thams cad kyis brgyan pa'i khang pa rin po che'i rgyan las shin tu 'das par gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i rin po che thams cad kyi dra bas kun nas yog par gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i rin po che thams cad kyi sprin gyi char mngon par 'bab par gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i rin po che thams cad kyi rgyan gyi sprin gyis brgyan par gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i gos thams cad kyi sprin rab tu gtong bar gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i tsan+dan thams cad kyi sprin chen po rab tu gtong bar gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i dri thams cad kyi mchog dang / bdug pa 'thul ba'i sprin gyi char rab tu 'bab par gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i rin po che sna tshogs thams cad kyi sprin rnam pa tha dad pa'i char rab tu 'bab par gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i me tog mang po'i sprin gyi tshogs kyi char rab tu 'bab par gnas so/ / lha rdzas las 'das pa'i sil snyan dang / brdung ba bye ba brgya stong bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i sgra rab tu 'byin par gnas so/ / thams cad mkhyen pa'i chos kyi dbyings su grag pa'i rol mo'i sgra dang / glu'i dbyangs kyang rab tu 'gyed par gnas par gyur te/ ji ltar bcom ldan 'das gshegs pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa dang / dga' ldan gyi gnas dag tu'ang rin po che thams cad kyis brgyan pa'i khang par gshegs par snang ngo/ /
de nas lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan gyis lha'i gnas thams cad du lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan gyis de bzhin gshegs pa la gsol ba btab bo/ / zhes sgra brjod do/ /
de nas sangs rgyas kyi mthus lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan la bar chad du mi 'gyur ba dang / sngon gyi dge ba'i rtsa ba'i tshogs dang / tshad med pa'i dge ba'i rtsa bas brtan pa dang / mtha' yas par sems bskyed pa'i dad pa rnam par 'phel ba dang / shugs chen po yang dag par bskyed pa dang / dga' ba chen po shin tu bskyed pa dang / dge ba'i bsam pa rnam par sbyangs pa dang / thams cad mkhyen pa nyid du sems bskyed pas dga' bar bya ba dang / chos la bar chad med pa'i yid du 'gyur bar bya ba dang / chos rnams mi nyams par bya ba'i phyir dga' ldan gyi gnas kyi glu dang / rol mo brdung ba dang / dkrol ba'i sgra rgyun mi 'chad par gyur to/ /

Then the World Honored One, adorning himself with the adornments of Buddhahood, replete with magnificent virtues, in order to gladden all beings, in order that all enlightening beings develop profound understanding, so that all the celestial beings of the Tushita heaven increase in determination, so that the king of the Tushita heaven never tires of generosity and service, so that countless beings focus their attention on the Buddha and become inspired to seek enlightenment, so that countless types of beings see the endlessness of the Buddha’s roots of goodness, blessings, and virtues, so that they always be able to arouse pure faith, so that, seeing a Buddha, they serve without seeking anything, so that all of their aspirations be pure, so that they diligently amass roots of goodness without flagging, and so that they would vow to seek omniscience, the Buddha accepted the invitation of the celestial king and entered the palace adorned by all jewels. Just as in this world, the same thing transpired in all worlds in the ten directions.
At that point the hall adorned by all jewels naturally had wonderfully fine decorations, surpassing all the heavens, and atop the decorations were nets of all jewels covering all over, showering clouds of all the finest gems all over, showering clouds of all kinds of ornaments, clouds of all kinds of precious raiment, clouds of all kinds of sandalwood incenses, clouds of all kinds of solid fragrances, clouds of canopies adorned by all jewels, and clouds of bunches of inconceivably many flowers, producing everywhere inconceivable music praising the Enlightened One’s knowledge of all means of liberation, all in accord with the sublime truth. All these offerings were beyond those of the celestial beings.
Then in the Tushita palace rich music and singing continued ceaselessly. By the spiritual power of the Buddha, the mind of the king of Tushita was made imperturbable; his past roots of goodness all reached complete fulfillment, his good qualities became more firm and stable, he increased in pure faith, he aroused great vigor, conceived great joy, purified profound aspiration, made the determination for enlightenment, and placed his unwavering attention on the teaching, keeping it firmly in mind.

de nas lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan gyis sangs rgyas kyi mthus sngon gyi yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams la dge ba'i rtsa ba bskyed pa de dag rjes su dran nas de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the king of the Tushita heaven, empowered by the Buddha, recalled the roots of goodness he had planted with past Buddhas and said in verse,

bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / chags pa med pa'i zla bar mtshan gsol mtshan btags pa/ / pho brang mchog tu rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'di yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / ye shes mtha' yas dbang zhes bya bar mtshan btags pa/ / kha dog gser du rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis; ; kun tu mtha' yas spyan zhes bya bar mtshan btags pa/ / pad+mo'i rtse mor rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis; ; yan lag rin po che zhes bya bar mtshan btags pa/ / rin chen mdzod du rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis; ; dpal rab rgol ba'i stag ces bya bar mtshan btags pa/ / dbang po'i khang par rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / yon tan thams cad ston pa'i nyin mtshan btags pa/ / me tog snying por rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / yan lag 'od zer mtha' yas par ni mtshan btags pa/ / shing gis brgyan par rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / mgon po the tshom 'joms pa chos kyi rgyal mtshan de/ / rin chen khang par rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / mi yi seng+ge ye shes sgron ma mtha' yas pa/ / spos kyi rtse mor rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /
bkra shis dam pa gang zhig gis/ / sangs rgyas yon tan kun gyi 'byung gnas 'od mnga' ba/ / nor bus brgyan par rab gshegs pa/ / des ni 'dir yang bkra shis legs gyur cig /

There once was a Buddha, Unobstructed Moon, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this hall of adornment, Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha called Broad Knowledge, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this golden hall, Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha called Universal Eye, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this hall of adornment, Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha called Coral, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this jewel mine hall, Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha, Lion of Philosophy, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this mountain king hall, Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha called Sunlight, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this hall of flowers. Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha called Boundless Light, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this tree-adorned hall, Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha called Banner of Truth, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this jewel palace hall, Therefore this place is most auspcious.
There once was a Buddha called Lamp of Knowledge, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this fragrant mountain hall, Therefore this place is most auspicious.
There once was a Buddha called Light of Virtue, Most auspicious among the auspicious; He once entered this crystal hall, Therefore this place is most auspicious.

ji ltar lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan gyis sangs rgyas kyi mthus sngon gyi yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi yon tan brjod de glu'i dbyangs su tshigs su bcad pas rgyal ba gshegs pa mngon par bstod pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad na yang lha'i rgyal po rab dga' ldan rnams sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis glu'i dbyangs su tshigs su bcad cing / sngon gyi yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi yon tan rjod par byed cing / rgyal ba gshegs pa la yang mngon par bstod par gyur to/ /
As in this world the king of the Tushita heaven, by the power of the Buddha, eulogized Buddhas of the past, so also did the kings of the Tushita heavens in all worlds praise the virtues of Buddhas.

de nas bcom ldan 'das chos kyi sku shin tu rnam par dag pa'i sku dang / 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad dang rigs gcig tu gyur pas rnam par 'phrul pa dang / rgyud kyi tshul gcig tu gyur bas sangs rgyas thams cad kyi rjes su thugs su chud pa'i thams cad mkhyen pa nyid dang / chos thams cad la bsgribs pa med par khyab pa'i sangs rgyas kyi spyan dang / chos kyi dbyings mtha' dang dbus med pa thams cad du sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs rgyun mi 'chad pa dang / sems can 'dul ba ji lta ba bzhin du yongs su khyab pa'i sangs rgyas kyi cho 'phrul dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku bsgribs pa med pa'i rgyan gyis yang dag par brgyan pa dang / dus bzhin du byung ba'i chos bstan pa/

Then the World Honored One sat crosslegged on the jewel treasury lion throne in the hall adorned by all jewels. His body of reality was pure, his inconceivable action was free. He was in the same realm as all Buddhas of all times, abiding in omniscience, entering into the same one essence with all the Buddhas. His enlightened eye was perfectly clear, and he saw all things without hindrance. He had great mystic powers, coursing everywhere throughout the cosmos unceasingly. He had great occult powers, able to go anywhere there might be beings who could be taught. His body was adorned with the unobstructed embellishments of all Buddhas. He was well aware of appropriate timing in expounding teachings to people.

byang chub sems dpa' brjod du med pa sangs rgyas kyi zhing sna tshogs nas lhags pa'i 'khor gyi dkyil 'khor rnam par dag pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i skus yang dag par spyod pa/ gnyis su med pa'i chos kyi sku la gnas pa'i sangs rgyas khyu mchog gi mthu phyung bas/ rin po che thams cad kyis brgyan pa'i khang par gshegs nas gdan bting ba la skyil mo krung bcas te bzhugs so/ / ji ltar bcom ldan 'das bzhugs pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad du yang bzhugs par gyur te/ ji ltar bcom ldan 'das rin po che thams cad kyis brgyan pa'i khang par gshegs pa dang / byon pa'i tshe sangs rgyas kyi rim gro dang / mchod pa byas shing rgyan gyis brgyan pa de dag thams cad pas/ de bzhin gshegs pa gdan de la bzhugs pa'i tshe grangs med pa'i yang grangs med pa'i rnam par lha rdzas las 'das pa'i me tog dang / phreng ba dang / byug pa dang / spos dang / phye ma dang / na bza' dang / gdugs dang / rgyal mtshan dang / ba dan dang / rin po che dang / rol mo brdung pa dang / dkrol ba dang / glu dang / bstod pa dang / rje sa dang / rim gro dang / dad pa dang / dga' ba dang / thal mo sbyar ba dang / lha rdzas las 'das pa rnam pa grangs med pa'i rgyan dang / lha rdzas las 'das pa rnam pa grangs med pa'i bstod pa dang / lha rdzas las 'das pa rnam pa grangs med pa'i sprin gyi char 'bab pa dang / lha rdzas las 'das pa rnam pa grangs med pa'i gdugs gcig nas gcig tu brgyud de bsgreng ba dang / lha rdzas las 'das pa rnam pa grangs med pa'i rgyal mtshan la ba dan dpyangs pa dang / shin tu dpyangs pa grangs med pas sbyar ba/ lha rdzas las 'das pa'i yo byad kyi tshul dang bsam pa rgya chen po rnam par 'phel bas sangs rgyas mnyes par bya ba dang / mdzes pa'i rgyan rnam par dag par thams cad kyi rin po che'i dri thams cad dang / phyogs brgyan pa'i spos kyi sprin chen po dang / rim gro'i rnam pa sna tshogs rgya che zhing yid du 'ong bas sangs rgyas la mchod pa dang / 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad rim gro la brtson pas de bzhin gshegs pa gdan la bzhugs pa'i tshe grangs med pa'i rgyun du mchod pa byas so/ / de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi dga' ldan gyi gnas dag tu yang mchod pa byas par gyur to/ /

Unspeakably many enlightening beings came from various lands in other regions and assembled; the congregation was pure, their reality-body nondual; they rested on nothing, and were freely able to perform the actions of Buddhas.
When the Buddha had sat on this throne, in the hall there spontaneously appeared countless adornments surpassing all the offerings of the celestials. That is, flower garlands, robes, perfumes, incense, jeweled parasols, banners, pennants, music, and singing. Each of these was uncountable. With great reverence and respect these were offered to the Buddha. The same thing took place in all the Tushita heavens in the ten directions.

shin tu rgyas pa chen po'i mdo/ sangs rgyas phal po che zhes bya ba las/ de bzhin gshegs pa dga' ldan du bzhud pa dang / gshegs pa dang / bzhugs pa'i rgyan ces bya ba'i le'u ste/ nyi shu brgyad pa'o// //
[29. dga' ldan gyi gnas su byang chub sems dpa' 'dus pa'i tshigs su bcad pa bstan pa'i le'u]
BOOK TWENTY-FOUR. Eulogies in the Tushita Palace
bam po sum cu gcig pa/

de nas sangs rgyas kyi mthus phyogs bcu kun nas byang chub sems dpa' bcu mngon par lhags te/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag so so nas 'jig rten gyi khams sangs rgyas kyi zhing stong phrag bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi pha rol nas 'ongs par gyur pa dag ste/ byang chub sems dpa' de dag re re zhing yang sangs rgyas kyi zhing stong phrag bcu'i rdul shin tu phra ba snyed kyi byang chub sems dpa' dag dang lhan cig tu phyin to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang ming 'di zhes bya ba dag ste/ 'di ltar rdo rje'i rgyal mtshan dang / dam pa'i rgyal mtshan dang / dpa' ba'i rgyal mtshan dang / skar ma'i rgyal mtshan dang / ye shes kyi rgyal mtshan dang / rin po che'i rgyal mtshan dang / rdul dang bral ba'i rgyal mtshan dang / dri ma med pa'i rgyal mtshan dang / dpal gyi rgyal mtshan dang / chos kyi rgyal mtshan zhes bya ba dag go /byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'jig rten gyi khams ming 'di zhes bya ba dag nas 'ongs par gyur pa dag ste/ 'di ltar rin po che'i snying po dang / yid du 'ong ba'i snying po dang / dngul gyi snying po dang / gser gyi snying po dang / nor bu'i snying po dang / rdo rje'i snying po dang / pad+mo'i snying po dang / ut+pa la'i snying po dang / tsan+dan gyi snying po dang / spos kyi snying po zhes bya ba dag go / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan 'di zhes bya ba dag gi zham 'bring na tshangs par spyod pa dag ste/ 'di ltar shin tu 'phags pa'i dpal dang / g.yo ba med pa'i dpal dang / bcings pa med pa'i dpal dang / spyod pa'i dpal dang / 'od zer gyi dpal dang / mtha' las rgal ba'i dpal dang / mchog gi dpal dang / dbang phyug gi dpal dang / tshangs pa'i dpal dang / shin tu bsags pa'i dpal zhes bya ba dag go /

THEN, DUE TO THE SPIRITUAL FORCE of the Buddha, a great enlightening being from each of the ten directions, each accompanied by as many enlightening beings as atoms in ten thousand buddha-lands, came to where the Buddha was, from worlds beyond lands as numerous as atoms in ten thousand buddha-lands. Their names were Diamond Banner, Banner of Steadfastness, Banner of Bravery, Banner of Light, Banner of Knowledge, Jewel Banner, Banner of Energy, Banner of Purification, Constellation Banner, and Banner of Truth. The worlds they came from were called Fine Jewel World, Fine Music World, Fine Silver World, Fine Gold World, Fine Crystal World, Fine Diamond World, Fine Lotus World, Fine Blue Lotus World, Fine Sandalwood World, and Fine Fragrance World. They each purified and cultivated religious practice with Buddhas, the names of which Buddhas were Banner of Inexhaustibility, Wind Banner, Banner of Liberation, Banner of Dignity, Banner of Understanding of Characteristics, Banner of Eternity, Banner of Supreme Excellence, Banner of Freedom, Banner of Purity, and Banner of Observation.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' de dag bcom ldan 'das la phyag 'tshal nas phyogs bcu rgyas par byas te/ gang nas 'ongs pa'i phyogs su brten nas seng+ge'i khri rin po che'i snying po can/ nor bu sna tshogs dang ldan pa dag mngon par sprul te gser gyi dra bas g.yogs pa'i lus dang / 'od zer bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong grangs med pa gtong pa dang / dri ma med pa'i 'od gtong pa dang / tshad med pa'i 'od rab tu bskyed pa dang / bsam pa rnam par dag pa'i rin po che yang dag par 'dzin pa'i gzugs dang / byang chub sems dpa'i bsam pa kha na ma tho ba med pa las byung ba'i smon lam dang / 'gro ba thams cad kyis blta na yid du 'ong ba dang / blta na don yod par sems can gdul ba dang / rnam par dag pa'i chos kyis sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa yongs su ston pa dang / 'gro ba thams cad yongs su bskyab par byang chub sems dpa'i rtse gcig tu smon lam btab pas skyil mo krung bcas te 'khod do/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag thams cad kyang 'di lta ste/ chags pa med par spyod pas sangs rgyas kyi zhing thams cad du 'gro ba dang / 'di lta ste/ gnas pa med pa'i lus dang / 'di lta ste/ tshad med pa'i lus kyis kun tu 'gro ba'i ye shes kyi lus kyi byin gyi rlabs dang / 'di lta ste/ mtha' dang dbus med pa'i sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa la 'jug pa dang / 'di lta ste/ thams cad mkhyen pa'i sgo 'byams klas pa tshad med par gyur pa dang / 'di lta ste/ chos la mi 'jigs par mkhas pa'i snang ba mtha' yas pa dang / 'di lta ste/ phyi ma'i mtha'i bskal par mi zad pa'i tha dad pa yang dag par shes pa'i tshul bshad pa dang / 'di lta ste/ gzugs thams cad kyis snang bar byas pa'i ye shes kyi phung bo rab tu rgyas pa dang / 'di lta ste/ chos kyi dbyings rgyas par gyur pa'i shes rab kyi mig rnam par dag pa'i spobs pa dang / 'di lta ste/ nam mkha'i dbyings kyis klas par ye shes kyi spyod yul yongs su gnas pa dang / mtshams med cing mtha' yas pa'i sangs rgyas rnams kyi spyod pa dang ldan pa rab tu thob par gyur pa dag go/ ji ltar gling bzhi pa 'di'i dga' ldan gyi gnas su byang chub sems dpa' 'dus pa gyur pa de bzhin du 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad kyi gling bzhi pa dang / dga' ldan gyi gnas dag tu yang byang chub sems dpa' ming de skad ces bya ba dag 'jig rten gyi khams ming de skad ces bya ba dag nas de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan de skad ces bya ba dag gi zham ring na tshangs par spyod pa sha stag 'ongs par gyur to/ /

When those enlightening beings arrived at the Buddha’s spot, they prostrated themselves before the Buddha; then, by the Buddha’s mystic power he magically produced lion seats of masses of beautiful jewels covered with nets of jewels all around, and the hosts of enlightening beings, according to the direction from which they had come, sat on those seats, Their bodies all emanated countless beams of pure light. This boundless light all came from the enlightening beings’ pure mind-jewels, their great vows which were free from all evils. They revealed the pure phenomena of the powers of all Buddhas. By the power of the impartial vision of all enlightening beings they were able to universally save all sentient beings. They were a gladdening sight in all worlds; those who saw them did not do so in vain — all attained harmony and tranquility.
Those enlightening beings had all already perfected innumerable virtues: for example, they traveled to all buddha-lands without hindrance; they saw the pure body of reality which rests on nothing; with the body of knowledge they manifested countless bodies going everywhere in the ten directions to serve the Buddhas; they entered into the Buddhas’ innumerable, boundless, inconceivable powers; they dwelt in the medium of omniscience; by the light of knowledge they comprehended all things; they had attained fearlessness in all respects; they taught wherever they were, their powers of elucidation forever inexhaustible; with great knowledge and wisdom they opened the gate of concentration spells; with the eye of wisdom they entered the profound realm of truth; the realm of their knowledge was boundless and ultimately pure, like space itself.
As in the palace of the Tushita heaven in this world the hosts of enlightening beings gathered like this, the same thing transpired in all the Tushita heavens in the ten directions; the names of the enlightening beings who gathered, the names of their countries, and the Buddhas there were all the same.

de nas bcom ldan 'das kyi zhabs pus mo'i lha nga gnyis nas 'od zer bye ba khrag khrig brgya phrag stong byung ste/ phyogs bcu thams cad snang bar byas nas 'jig rten gyi khams thams cad bstan to/ / de nas byang chub sems dpa' de dag gis 'jig rten gyi khams de dag gi gling bzhi pa thams cad dang / dga' ldan gyi gnas thams cad na de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par 'phrul pa yod par mthong bar gyur to/ / byang chub sems dpa' de dag ji snyed kyis phyogs bcur chos kyi dbyings kyis klas pa'i 'jig rten gyi khams kyi mthar thug pa dag na de bzhin gshegs pa'i rnam par rol pa mthong bar gyur pa de dag thams cad de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rnam par snang mdzad kyi sngon byang chub sems dpa'i spyod pa la dge ba'i rtsa ba'i grogs su gyur pa dag ste/ 'di ltar sangs rgyas kyi rnam par thar pa zab mos rnam par 'phrul ba la mos pa sha stag go/ chos kyi dbyings kyi lus tha dad pa med pa'i rjes su song ba sha stag go/ gnas med pa'i sangs rgyas kyi zhing du 'gro ba'i rjes su song bas rab tu zhugs pa sha stag go /sangs rgyas bsam gyis mi khyab pa lta ba la rjes su gzhol ba sha stag go /chags pa med pa'i sems skad cig gis chos kyi dbyings khyab par byed pa sha stag go /bsam pa rin po che rdul dang bral ba dang ldan pa sha stag go /brjod du med pa'i sangs rgyas mang po dang 'grogs pa dang ldan pa sha stag go /sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs grangs med pa dang ldan pa sha stag go/ yang dag pa spyod pa'i mchog gi pha rol tu phyin pa sha stag go /bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub kyi dran pa rnam par dag pa la gnas pa sha stag go / blo dang sems skad cig thams cad kyis cher 'phags pa rab tu thob pa sha stag go /chung ngur zhugs shing cher gyur pa'i spyod pa la dbang ba sha stag go / cher gyur pa la zhugs shing chung ngur 'jug pa'i rjes su chud nas ye shes kyi spyod pa'i pha rol tu phyin pa sha stag go /de lta bu'i gnas dang / sangs rgyas kyi sku'i rang bzhin rjes su rtogs pa dang / de bzhin gshegs pa dang 'grogs shing thams cad mkhyen pa nyid thob pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams dang / rin po che sna tshogs ltar grub pa'i lus dang / de bzhin gshegs par gyur pa'i spyod yul thams cad du 'gro ba dang / ye shes chen po'i rgyud kyi sgo rnam par phye ba dang / ye shes kyi stobs rdo rje'i rgyal mtshan gyi mthu'i mchog thob pa dang / rdo rje gcod pa'i ting nge 'dzin gyi tshul rab tu thob pa dang / sems can bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong grangs med pa rnams yongs su smin par gdul ba la rmongs pa med pa dang / sangs rgyas kyi rnam par 'phrul ba thams cad du 'gro ba gdon mi za ba'i mchog thob pa dang / bgrang ba thams cad la mngon par ma chags pa dang / bgrang ba mngon par sgrub pa thams cad shin tu bslab pa dang / bgrang ba'i shes pa thams cad kyis mthar thug cing chos rnam par dgod pa la mkhas pa 'di dag dang / gzhan yang yon tan bye ba khrag khrig brgya stong brjod du med pa/ yon tan bsngags pa rnam par dag pa mi zad pas byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi dus gsum gyi yon tan tshad med pa dang ldan pa sha stag de bzhin gshegs pa mngon sum du bya ba dang / sangs rgyas 'byams klas pa thams cad blta ba'i phyir kun nas 'dus par gyur to/ /

Then the World Honored One emanated countless beams of light from the wheel marks on his knees, illuminating the entire space of the cosmos in the ten directions. The enlightening beings in all worlds all saw this miraculous display of the Buddha, and the enlightening beings here saw the miraculous displays of all the Buddhas in other worlds. These enlightening beings had all similarly planted roots of goodness in the distant past along with Vairocana Buddha, cultivating enlightening practice; they all had awakened to and entered the free, extremely profound liberation of the Buddhas, and had attained the undifferentiated cosmic body, entering all lands without dwelling anywhere. They saw countless Buddhas and went to serve them all. In a single mental instant they traversed the cosmos, freely and without hindrance. Their minds and intellects were pure, like priceless jewels. Innumerable Buddhas always guarded them mindfully, sharing their power with them. They reached the ultimate, supreme other shore; by pure mindfulness they continually dwelt in highest awareness; in every moment of thought they continually entered into the realm of omniscience; they put the small in the large and the large in the small, free in all ways, with no obstruction whatsoever. They had already attained the buddha-body and dwelt in the same abode as the Buddhas; they had attained omniscience and produced their bodies from omniscience. They were able to enter the spheres of action of all enlightened ones. They opened up innumerable gates of knowledge and wisdom. They reached the other shore of indestructible great knowledge, attained adamantine concentration, and cut off all doubts and confusion. They had attained the autonomous spiritual powers of Buddhas, teaching and taming countless numbers of sentient beings in the lands of the ten directions. Though they had no attachments to any categories or phenomena, they were were able to learn and develop ultimate skill in use of doctrines and to establish all teachings conducive to enlightenment.
Hosts of enlightening beings with such infinite treasuries of all inexhaustible pure virtues of past, present, and future all came and assembled at the Buddha’s place; the same thing occurred at the places of all the Buddhas revealed by the light.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' rdo rje'i rgyal mtshan gyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Diamond Banner, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

yang dag sangs rgyas skye ba med/ / rgyal ba mya ngan mi 'da' ste/ / rgyu mthun pa yi smon lam gyis/ / des ni rnam par 'phrul pa snang / /
'di dag chos ni bsam mi khyab/ / 'di dag sems kyi spyod yul min/ / gang gis ye shes pha rol phyin/ / des ni sangs rgyas spyod yul mthong / /
lus 'di yang dag sangs rgyas min; ; sgra yang de bzhin gshegs pa min/ / lus dang sgra las gzhan na yang / / sangs rgyas rnam par 'phrul mi mthong / /
sngon gyi las rnams ma gtogs par/ / rang byung rnams kyi spyod yul gyi/ / mchog gi tshul rnams shes pa ni/ / blo zhan rnams kyis mi nus so/ /
yang dag sangs rgyas rnam 'phrul 'di/ / gang dag nas kyang ma 'ongs te/ / gang du'ang 'gro bar mi 'gyur ro/ / 'di dag rang byung sku yin no/ /
tshad med shin tu 'dren pa rnams/ / chos 'di rab tu bshad mdzad kyang / / chos la gnas pa gang yang med/ / zhing rnams bye ba kun na snang / /
mkhyen pa mtha' dang dbus med de/ / chos kun thugs su chud cing rtogs/ / chos kyi dbyings la rab zhugs nas/ / rnam par 'phrul pa ston pa mdzad/ /
chos rnams kun la chags pa med/ / 'gro la de ni bsgribs mi mnga'/ / tshad med pa yi yon tan gyis/ / zhing rnams kun na rab tu snang / /
gang zhig ye shes 'di dag dang / / ye shes thams cad rtogs 'dod pas/ / bsam pa rnam par sbyangs byas te/ / byang chub spyod pa spyad par bya/ /
drang srong chen po'i byin gyi rlabs/ / 'di 'dra gang gis mthong gyur cing / / de ni the tshom mi byed na/ / dge bshes mchog la brten pa yin/ /

The Buddha does not appear in the world And has no extinction either: By the power of his great original vow He demonstrates his freedom.
This truth is inconceivable— It is not in the sphere of mind: When knowledge reaches the other shore One then sees the realm of the Buddhas.
The physical body is not the Buddha, Neither is the audible voice: Yet not apart from form and sound Can Buddha’s mystic power be perceived.
Those of little knowledge cannot know The true realm of the Buddhas; After long cultivation of purifying action Will one be able to comprehend.
The Truly Awake comes from nowhere And also goes nowhere: The pure, refined physical body Appears through spiritual power.
Manifesting the body of an enlightened one In innumerable worlds, Widely expounding the subtle teachings, His mind has no attachments.
His knowledge, being boundless, Comprehends all things; Entering everywhere in the universe, He manifests autonomous powers.
Sentient beings and all phenomena He comprehends unhindered; Everywhere manifesting physical forms, He is omnipresent in all lands.
If you want to see omniscience And soon attain highest awareness, You should, with pure clear mind, Cultivate enlightening practice.
If any see such mystic powers Of the Enlightened One, They should serve the Supreme Honored One And not give rise to doubt.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' dam pa'i rgyal mtshan gyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas nas de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then the enlightening being Banner of Steadfastness, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

shin tu zab ste brjod du med/ / brjod du yod kyang 'da' bar dka'/ / tshig gi lam las shin tu 'das/ / nam mkha' la ni rgyal ba snang / /
de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin rlabs kyis/ / mi yi seng+ge mthong bar 'gyur/ / yang dag sangs rgyas rtogs mad [*med?] kyang / / rgyal ba rnam par rtog par snang / /
'jig rten mgon pos chos nyid dngos/ / zab mo 'di dag yang dag bstan/ / gang zag mtshungs pa med pa yi/ / des ni sku 'dir rab tu 'byung / /
thams cad gzigs kyi spyod yul gyi/ / ye shes chen po 'di 'dra ste/ / 'di la gang zhig rtogs 'dod pa/ / des na rgyal ba mngon du byos/ /
yid kyi dbang po rnam dag pas/ / de bzhin gshegs pa bsnyen bkur zhing / / 'di yi tshul las 'da' byed tshe/ / nam yang skyo bar mi bya'o/ /
mi zad pa yi bsod nams dang / / byang chub sems kyis brtan pa rnams/ / the tshom rnam par bzlog byas te/ / de dag la ni skyo med ltos/ /
rgyal sras gang gis chos dbyings kyi/ / shin tu bstan pa'i mthar phyin pa/ / des ni kun gzigs rnam 'phrul ba/ / 'di dag shin tu 'da' bar bya;
dad pa chos 'di'i rtsa ba zhes/ / chos kyi phung pos bshad mdzad kyi/ / dad pa shin tu cher bskyed la/ / byang chub spyod pa spyad par gyis/ /
sangs rgyas bsti stang gang byed cing / / de bzhin gshegs la drin gzo ba/ / yang dag sangs rgyas dpal ldan las/ / de dag rgyang mar mi gnas so/ /
bdag nyid che ba 'di lta bu; ; gang zhig thos mthong mkhas pa rnams/ / spyod yul thob par cir 'gyur ba'i/ / smon lam su zhig sbyong mi byed/ /

The Enlightened One is incomparable, Most profound, inexplicable, Beyond all manner of speech, Pure as space itself.
Behold the Human Lion’s Autonomous mystic power, Beyond discrimination, Yet causing distinct perceptions.
In order to expound The profound and subtle teaching The Guide, for this reason, Manifests this peerless body.
This is great knowledge, The realm of all the Buddhas; If any want to know, Let them approach the Enlightened.
With mental action always pure, Making offerings to the Buddhas With never any weariness, One can enter the Buddha Way.
Filled with endless virtues, Steadfast in the will for enlightenment, Thereby the net of doubt is removed And one gazes tirelessly on the Buddha.
By comprehending all things Does one become a true child of Buddha: Such a person can know The Buddhas’ autonomous power.
As explained by those of vast knowledge, Will is the root of the teachings; One must develop supreme aspiration, Determined to seek highest awakening.
If any respect the Buddha And want to requite the Buddha’s grace, They will never leave The abode of all the Buddhas.
How can intelligent people Who’ve seen and heard the Buddha Not carry out pure vows And tread the path the Buddha traversed?
de nas byang chub sems dpa' dpa' ba'i rgyal mtshan gyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas nas de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then Banner of Bravery, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

ji ltar nyi ma'i 'od snang bas/ / mig gis gzugs rnams mthong gyur pa/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas byin rlabs kyis/ / dag pa'i sems ldan rgyal ba mthong / /
ji ltar brtson 'grus stobs ldan pa/ / rgya mtsho la ni 'jug par byed/ / de bzhin ye shes stobs ldan pas/ / bsam du med pa'i sangs rgyas mthong / /
ji ltar sa bon rnam pa dag / zhing bzang la ni skyer 'gyur pa; ; de bzhin sems bsam rnam dag la/ / sangs rgyas chos ni skye bar 'gyur/ /
ji ltar nor gyi phung po yis/ / dbul ba thams cad spong byed pa/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas chos rnams kyis/ / byang chub sems dpa' rnam dag 'gyur/ /
ji ltar dug tu gyur pa la/ / nad med dug sman rgyal bar byed/ / de bzhin nyon mongs rnam pa la/ / rnam dag tshul ni spyod yul lo/ /
sangs rgyas kyis ni gang bsngags pa'i/ / dge ba'i bshes la brten byas na/ / de yi mthus ni sangs rgyas kyi/ / chos nyid 'di dag thos par 'gyur/ /
bskal pa bye ba grangs med par/ / sbyin pa mchog rnams sbyin byas kyang / / 'di yi tshul la rab spyod pa'i/ / grangs dang char yang mi 'gro 'o/ /
sangs rgyas yon tan mtha' yas te/ / mtshan gyis shin tu rnam par bris/ / brjod pas yang dag sangs rgyas rnams/ / rgyal ba shes par mi nus so/ /
rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rkang gnyis mchog / gnas nas g.yo ba mi mnga' bar/ / sku ni kun tu rnam rgyu zhing / / chos kyi dbyings ni ston pa mdzad/ /
ji ltar nam mkha'i khams 'di ni/ / nam yang rang bzhin mi 'gyur te/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas chos nyid kyang / / ngo bo nyid las 'gyur ba med/ /

Just as a clear eye Can see colors due to the sun, So too can a pure heart See the Enlightened by Buddha’s power.
As by the power of effort One can plumb the depths of the sea, So too can the power of knowledge See innumerable Buddhas.
As in a fertile, watered field Whatever’s planted will grow, So does the ground of a pure mind Produce enlightened qualities.
As a man who’s found a jewel mine Is forever freed from poverty, An enlightening being finding the Buddha teaching Is free from defilement, pure in mind.
Just as a true panacea Can eliminate all toxins, Buddha’s teaching too is like this: It annihilates all afflictions.
Truly genuine teachers Are praised by the enlightened: Through their spiritual power We get to hear the Buddha teachings.
Even if for countless cons One gave precious things to Buddha, If one doesn’t know the real nature of Buddha This is not called giving.
Infinite physical characteristics Adorn the Buddha’s body; Yet it is not in physical form That the Buddha can be seen.
The Enlightened One, Truly Awake, Is peaceful, never moving, Yet can manifest his body Throughout all worlds in the ten directions.
Just as space itself Is unborn and unperishing, So is the truth of the Buddhas Ultimately birthless and deathless.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' skar ma'i rgyal mtshan gyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then Banner of Light, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

mi yi 'jig rten 'di kun dang / / lha yi gnas rnams thams cad dang / / 'gro ba ma lus kun na yang / / mi yi gtso bo shin tu snang / /
ji ltar sems dngos gcig pu las/ / rnam pa tha dad sems brjod pa/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas sku gcig las/ / sangs rgyas thams cad brjod pa yin; ;
byang chub gnyis su med par brjod/ / byang chub de yang mtshan nyid med/ / mtshan gyis mngon par rnam bris pa'i/ / sku rnams gnyis su snang bar gyur/ /
mkha' dang chos kyi dbyings la zhugs/ / sgyu ma'i sa yang rab tu bstan/ / de phyir sangs rgyas de dag gi / spyod yul lta ba zad pa med/ /
yang dag sangs rgyas chos kyi sku/ / mgon po thams cad dus gsum du/ / ji ltar 'dul ba'i 'gro ba la/ / gzugs kyi skur yang rab tu snang / /
'di 'dra'i lus su bdag gyur ces/ / sangs rgyas rtog par mi mdzad de/ / ston la rnam rtog mi mnga' yang / / byin gyi rlabs ni ston par mdzad/ /
dbyer med pa yi dbyings la yang / / chos kyi dbyings ni yang dag gnas/ / 'jig rten khams ni tshad med par/ / thub pas rnam par rtog pa bstan/ /
sku ni sprul pa ma yin te/ / sprul min pa yang sku ma yin/ / sprul pa med pa'i chos 'di yis/ / sprul pa rnams ni rab tu bstan/ /
yang dag sangs rgyas tshad med pa/ / chos kyi dbyings la shin tu brten/ / mtha' dang dbus med rab tu zab/ / tshig gi lam gyis bzla bar dka'/ /
kun tu 'gro ba'i chos rnams la/ / de bzhin gshegs pa don des mkhyen/ / zhing rnams kun la chags mi mnga'/ / chos kyi dbyings la rnam par spyod/ /

In the human and celestial realms In all the worlds there are They see everywhere the Enlightened One’s Body of pure wondrous form.
Just as the power of one mind Can produce various minds, So can one buddha-body Manifest all Buddhas everywhere.
Enlightenment is nondual And also has no marks: Yet in the realm of duality He manifests a glorified body.
Comprehending the nature of things is empty, Their origination like apparitions, His realm of action’s inexhaustible: Thus does the Guide appear.
Pure is the reality-body Of all Buddhas of all times; They manifest sublime physical forms Wherever and however people need to be taught.
The enlightened do not think “I’ll produce such a body”: They manifest spontaneously Without discriminating.
The realm of reality is undifferentiated And also has no basis: And yet in the world It manifests countless bodies.
The Buddha’s bodies are not emanations And yet not other than emanations: In the reality where there are no emanations He appears to have emanated forms.
True awareness cannot be measured, The reality-realm’s equal to space; Profound, vast, without bound or bottom, Utterly beyond the power of speech.
The Enlightened One has mastered The road leading everywhere: Through the myriad lands of the cosmos He goes without obstruction.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' ye shes rgyal mtshan gyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then Banner of Knowledge, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

kun mkhyen ye shes ma chags pa/ / de la zhugs pa gang gyur pa/ / de yi sems ni tshad mi zin/ / byang chub kyi ni spyad pa spyod/ /
de bzhin gshegs pa mang po rnams; ; yul dang yul du de snang ba/ / chos rnams phyogs gcig gang la yang / / yang dag sangs rgyas gnas pa med/ /
'jig rten sgron ma de dag gis/ / byin gyi rlabs ni gang bstan pa/ / bskal pa bsam gyis mi khyab par/ / 'di yi mtha' ni rnyed par dka'/ /
dus gsum rnams ni ji snyed pa'i/ / sems can rnams kyi mthar thug pa/ / bgrang ba'i mthar ni phyin par nus/ / 'dren pa la ni mthar thug med/ /
de dag sku ni gcig tu snang / / sku gnyis de dag bsam mi khyab/ / 'jig rten khams su snang gyur kyang / / sku la gnyis su gyur pa med/ /
ji ltar zla ba shar gyur pa/ / tshad med pa yi gzugs brnyan rnams/ / chu yi snod du snang gyur kyang / / zla ba gnyis su gyur pa med/ /
de bzhin chags med mkhyen ldan rnams/ / chags med rnam par 'tshang rgya ba/ / zhing rnams kun na rab tu snang / / sangs rgyas la ni gnyis kyang med/ /
'di la gcig kyang yod ma yin/ / sku ni gnyis sam gsum du med/ / ji ltar sems can bsam pa bzhin/ / tshad med par ni rab tu snang / /
sku ni 'das pa ma yin te; ; ma 'ongs pa yang sku ma yin/ / skyes dang byang chub mya ngan 'das/ / skad cig gis ni rab tu snang / /
ji ltar sgyu mar gyur pa'i gzugs/ / skyes pa ma yin 'ongs pa min/ / de ltar de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku/ / skye ba med par shin tu bstan/ /

If one can believe and accept Omniscience without obstruction, And practice enlightening ways, One’s mind will be immeasurable.
In all lands Buddha manifests countless bodies, Yet the bodies stay in no place, And he dwells not in the real.
Each one of the Enlightened Manifest bodies by spiritual powers: Even in unthinkable eons They never could be fully counted.
The number of all living beings Of all times may be known, But the number of Buddhas’ manifestations Cannot ever be found.
Sometimes they show one or two, Up to countless bodies— Appearing everywhere, in all lands, Yet really with no duality.
Just as the clear full moon Appears in all bodies of water And while the reflections are numberless The real moon is not two,
So does the one of unimpeded knowledge With perfect true enlightenment Universally appear in all lands: Yet the Buddha-body is nondual.
It is not one, and yet not two, And also not immeasurable: According to the needs of the taught Do countless bodies appear.
The buddha-body is not past And also not future: In a single instant he appears to be born, To become enlightened, and pass away.
As forms produced by magic Have no birth and no origination, So too is the buddha-body thus— Appearing without any birth.
de nas byang chub sems dpa' rin po che'i rgyal mtshan gyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so/ /
Then Jewel Banner, empowered by the Buddha, looked over the ten directions and said in verse,

yang dag sangs rgyas tshad med par/ / tshad du sku yang rnam par bstan/ / ji ltar 'dul ba'i sems can rnams/ / de bzhin 'dren pa rab tu mthong / /
sku la phyogs ni med par brjod/ / sangs rgyas yul ni ma lus khyab/ / bar snang nam mkha' ji lta ba/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas bsam mi khyab/ /
der ni sems kyang 'pho ba med/ / sems la skye ba'ang yod ma yin/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi spyod yul ni/ / skye ba med la rab tu gnas/ /
ji ltar rab rib ldan pa'i mig / nang na med cing phyi na'ang med/ / de bzhin 'jig rten sangs rgyas dag / nang na mi bzhugs phyi na'ang min; ;
'jig rten kun gyi don gyi phyir/ / rkang gnyis kyi ni mchog byung ste/ / 'jig rten du ni ma byung yang / / 'jig rten dag tu skye bos mthong / /
sangs rgyas rnams la zhing mi gnas; ; rgyal ba dag la nyin mtshan med/ / skad cig ma yin zla ba min/ / rgyal ba la ni lo mi gnas/ /
'jig rten dag na ji skad brjod/ / nyi ma che ge mo zhig tu/ / rang byung byang chub rgyal bas thob/ / sangs rgyas nyi ma'i rjes mi 'brang / /
de la bskal pa yod ma yin/ / dus kyang ma lus med pa ste/ / dus gsum yang dag rdzogs sangs rgyas/ / mgon po rnams ni mnga' bar 'gyur/ /
ji ltar nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor ni/ / nam yang mtshan dang mi gnas te/ / nyin mtshan zhes kyang rab tu brjod/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas chos nyid do/ /
bskal pa gcig dang dus gsum du/ / 'dren pa bzhugs pa ma yin te/ / dus gsum zhes kyang rab tu brjod/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi chos nyid ltos/ /

The buddha-body is infinite Yet can manifest finite bodies: According to what needs to be seen Does the Guide appropriately appear.
The buddha-body has no location, Yet fills all places; Like space, it’s boundless: Such is its inconceivability.
It is not in the province of mental function, And mind does not arise therein: In the realm of the Buddhas Ultimately there’s no birth or death.
Like what is seen by clouded eyes Is neither internal nor external, So also, you should know, Is the worlds’ vision of the Buddhas.
In order to benefit living beings Do the Enlightened Ones appear in the world: Sentient beings see them as coming forth, But in reality there is no such thing.
A Buddha cannot be seen In terms of a land, or day or night, Nor indeed can one be seen In terms of years, months, or moments.
Sentient beings say Buddha was enlightened on a certain day; But enlightenment in reality Is not bound to time.
The Enlightened are beyond discrimination: Not of the world, they transcend all accounts— All Guides of past, present, and future Appear in this way.
Just as the pure orb of the sun Doesn’t conjoin with the dark night, Yet we speak of such and such a day and night, So is the principle of the Buddhas;
Though the ages of past, present, and future Do not conjoin with the Enlightened, Yet we speak of the Buddhas of past, present, and future: Such is the principle of the Guides.

de nas byang chub sems dpa' rdul dang bral ba'i rgyal mtshan gyis sangs rgyas kyi byin gyi rlabs kyis phyogs bcur rnam par bltas te/ de'i tshe tshigs su bcad pa 'di dag smras so// yang dag sangs rgyas sku gcig ste/ /
Then Banner of Energy, empowered by the Buddha, looked over ten directions and said in verse,

'dren pa thams cad don gcig kyang / / tshad med gzhan dang gzhan dag tu/ / phyogs bcu kun na rab tu snang / / gang gis ma lus thams cad kyi; ;
chos kyi dbyings rnams kun khyab pa/ / sems can gtso bo thub pa yi/ / spyod yul rnams ni ci 'dra ltos/ / sangs rgyas rnams kyi chos nyid ni; ;
nang gi skus kyang snang ba min/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i byin gyi rlabs/ / phyi rol skus kyang mi snang ngo/ / dus mang kun tu las rnams kyis/ /
ji ltar las rnams bsags pa bzhin/ / de bzhin so sor phye ba'i skus/ / rigs su byung bar rab tu bstan/ / rgyal ba'i chos nyid ma gtogs par/ /
sangs rgyas sku ni 'di 'dra ba/ / grangs su bgrang bar mi nus te/ / bsam pas lta yang shes mi nus/ / ji ltar bdag cag sems kyis las/ /
bsam gyis mi khyab mi 'byung ba/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas bsam mi khyab; ; sems kyi 'phrin las mi mnga' 'o/ / ji ltar zhing rnams bsam yas pa/ /
sa la rnam par dag pas mdzes/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas bsam mi khyab/ / 'gro ba dag na mdzes par snang / / ji ltar las rnams 'jug pa ni/ /
rkyen gyis rab tu 'byung 'gyur ba/ / de bzhin rgyu rnams mthun pa las/ / sangs rgyas shin tu mthong bar 'gyur/ / yid bzhin nor bu'i rgyal po ni/ /
ji ltar yid bsam rdzogs byed pa/ / de bzhin sangs rgyas chos nyid kyang / / rtag tu smon lam rdzogs par sgrub/ / mtha' dang dbus med 'jig rten 'dir/ /
'jig rten mgon po 'dren par 'gyur/ / de yi smon lam de dag gis/ / phyogs bcu 'di dag rgyal bas gang / /

All the Guides’ Bodies are the same, as are their meanings; Throughout the lands of the ten directions They appear variously according to needs.
Observe the Honored Sage: His activity is most unique; He fills the entire cosmos And everything that’s in it.
The buddha-body is not within And also not outside: It manifests by spiritual power; Such is the teaching of the Guide.
According to deeds accumulated in former times By the various species of living beings, Such various different bodies Appear, each one dissimilar.
Thus the bodies of the Buddhas Are infinite, uncountable: Except for the great enlightened one No one can conceive of them.
Just as the self, being inconceivable, Cannot be grasped by mentation, So too the inconceivability of Buddhas Is not manifested by mentation.
